user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_date_header:
```c
static bool
get_date_header (char *header)
{
  if (! get_date_str (header + 6))
  {
    header[0] = 0;
    return false;
  }
  header[0] = 'D';
  header[1] = 'a';
  header[2] = 't';
  header[3] = 'e';
  header[4] = ':';
  header[5] = ' ';
  header[35] = '\r';
  header[36] = '\n';
  header[37] = 0;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
header[1] = 'a';
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the function writes into the buffer (header[1] = 'a'), so header must be a pointer to a modifiable char. Rule 8.13 requires const qualification only when the pointed-to object is not modified — here that is not the case. A true violation would be e.g. declaring a pointer as char * when it is only read (should be const char *), or attempting to modify a const-qualified/immutable object (e.g. modifying a string literal via header[1] = 'a').
